dictionary: @ A book that contains a list of words in alphabetical order and explains their meanings, or gives a word for them in another language; an electronic product giving similar information on a computer, smartphone, etc.
punctuation: The most common punctuation marks in English are: capital letters and full stops, question marks, commas, colons and semi-colons, exclamation marks and quotation marks.

syllable: In the word "engine", you should stress the first syllable.

typo: @ A small mistake in a text made when it was typed or printed.
The text was full of typos.
I saw only one error, just a typo on page 2, last sentence has consecutive instances of the word ' were '.
plural: @ a word or form that expresses more than one.
Geese is the plural of goose.
notation: @ A system of written symbols used esp. in mathematics or to represent musical notes.
Did you write things out in standard notation?

slang: @ A very informal language that is usually spoken rather than written, used especially by particular groups of people.
He used a lot of slang terms that I simply don't understand.

dialect: @ The differences in language depending on region.
& Dialect consist of their own slang terms.
@ For instance, in the south, we say words like "y'all" which means "you all".
collocation: @ A word or phrase that is often used with another word or phrase, in a way that sounds correct to people who have spoken the language all their lives, but might not be expected from the meaning.
In the phrase "a hard frost", ' hard ' is a collocation of ' frost ', and ' strong ' would not sound natural.

essay: @ A short piece of writing on a particular subject, often expressing personal views.
Taken as a group, these essays are based in deep research.

article: & An article is usually news oriented, an essay can be literary.

abbreviation: & An abbreviation is a shortened form that represents the whole word
& For instance, EX and Dr. is the abbreviation for Example and Doctor.
But others among us have less familiarity with some of the terms and abbreviations that pepper the site.

acronym: & An acronym uses initial letters from a phrase that forms one word.
@ A word created from the first letters of each word in a series of words.
NASA is an acronym for National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
PIPE is an acronym for private-investment, public-equity
To some, that acronym has become a dirty word.

decrease: & Diminish and decrease are both mean to get smaller. Usually diminish means to a greater degree, like almost complete gone.
decay: @ To become gradually damaged, worse, or less; to cause something to do this.
@ If a radioactie substance decays, it changes to a different form, producing radiation.
As the actinium-225 decays, it gives off short-lived, highly energized alpha particles.
trim: @ To make something neater or more level by cutting a small amount off it.
@ To reduce the amount or size of something
They're trying to trim their costs, so staff who leave are not being replaced.
@ To decorate something by adding objects, pieces of material, etc. that make it look attractive.
The edge of the jacket had been trimmed with sequins.
She was wearing a black suit trimmed with white.
@ Thin in an attractive and healthy way.
You're looking very trim - have you lost weight?
He was a short, trim, wiry man.
Trim lawns and neat flower beds.
@ An act of making something, esp. someone's hair, neater or more level by cutting a small amount off it.
I asked the hairdresser for a trim.
Just give the ends a trim, please.

in trim: @ Physically prepared and ready, or in good condition.
Are you in trim for the run on Sunday?

wiry: @ (of people and animals) thin but strong, and often able to bend easily.
He has a runner's wiry frame.

plunge: @ To (cause someone or something to) move or fall suddenly and often a long way forward, down, or into something.
We run down to the beach and plunged into the sea.
The car went out of control and plunged over the cliff.
Cook the peas by pluging them into boiling water.
Niagara Falls plunges one hundred sixty-five feet.
@ To become lower in value or level very suddenly and quickly.
The fall in demand caused stock prices to plunge.
@ A sudden movement or fall forward, down, or into something.
I really enjoyed my plunge in the pool.
@ A sudden and large fall in value or level.
We are expecting a plunge in profits this year.

ascent: @ The act of climbing or moving upward.
She made her first successful ascent of Everest last year.
As the plane made its ascent, we saw thick smoke coming from one engine.
@ A slope, path, or road that goes up something.
We struggled up the slippery ascent.
@ The fact of starting to become successful.
His ascent to power was rapid and unexpected.

destruction: @ The act of destroying something, or the fact of being destroyed.
Many people are very concerned about the destruction of the rainforests.
Unusually high winds left a trail of destruction over the area.

unspoilt: @ An un spoiled place is beautiful because it has not been changed or demaged by people.
An island with clean, unspoiled beaches.

overthrow: @ To defeat or remove someone from power, using force.
He said that Allende's government in Chile was overthrown by the army and the CIA in 1973.
@ To throw a ball past the person or object you intended to throw to.
@ An occasion when someone or something is removed from power using force.
@ The act of throwing a ball too far.

emancipate: @ To give people social or political freedom and rights.
Together they emancipated the art of experiment from being a mere craft activity and endowed it with the status of a science.
& Usually be used in official or legal contexts.

discharge: @ To allow someone officially to leave somewhere, especially a hospital or a law court.
Patients were discharged from the hospital because the beds were needed by other people.

manumit: In addition, they encouraged slaveholders to manumit their slaves.

neglect: The climate is naturally good, but continued neglect of sanitary precautions has made the city unhealthy.

ignore: & Ignore just means that someone doesn't pay attention. Neglect is leaving something alone to the point that it falls aparts or breaks.
omit: @ To fail to include or do something.
She was omitted from the list of contributors ot the report.
The Prince's tour conveniently omitted the most deprived areas of the city.
She omitted to mention that she would be away next week.

omission: Parents are upset by the omission of music from the school's courses.

illicit: As a port it was notorious of its smuggling and illicit trade.

illegal: & An illegal action only breaks the law. An illicit action breaks ethical or moral standards (and probably the law as well).
outrageous: It is outrageous that these buildings remain empty while thousands of people have no homes.
These prices are just outrageous (= much too high).
smuggle: He was arrested and charged with attemping to smuggle cocaine into Scotland.
bribe: @ To try to make someone do something for you by giving him or her money, presents, or something else that he or she wants.
He bribed immigration officials and entered the country illegally.
They bribed the waiter to find them a better table.
He discovered that certain corrupt officials had been bribed to approve shoddy construction work.
@ Money or present that you give to someone so that they will do something for you, usually something dishonest.
He was accused of accepting/taking bribes from wealthy businessmen.
court: @ The place where a judge decides if someone has done a crime
The suspect appeared in court charged with robbery.
@ An area for playing a sport.

charter: @ A formal statement of the rights of a country's people, or of an organization or a particular social group, that is agreed by or demanded from a ruler or government.
Education is one of the basic human rights written into the United Nations Charter.
The government has produced a Citizen's/Parents' /Patient's Charter.
@ To rent a vehicle, esp. an aircraft for a special use and not as part of a regular service.
They've chartered a plane to take delegates to the conference.

constitution: @ The set of political principles by which a state or organization is governed, esp. in relation to the rights of the people.
The first amendments to the Constitution of the United States are called the Bill of Rights.
Under the union constitution, a new committee is elected each year.
@ The general state of someone's health.
He has a very strong constitution.
@ How something is made up of different parts.
The constitution of a chemical compound.

constitutional: @ Allowed by or contained in a constitution.
Such a policy would not be constitutional.
Freedom of speech should be a constitutional right.
@ A walk that you often do to keep yourself healthy.
She's nearly 86 and still takes a constitutional every morning.
unconstitutional: @ Not allowed by the constitution of a country or organization.
Changing the law in this way would be unconstitutional.

statute: @ A law that has been formally approved and written down.
The salaries of most federal workers are set by statute.
Many state and federal statutes already cover identity theft.

statutory: @ Decided, controlled, or required by law.
In France everbody is entitled to a statutory 25 days a year holiday.
Commentators often mock statutory damages, especially for willful infringement, as being over the top.
And yet this program, which we found has no statutory basis and which is not very effective - this program continues today.
The proposal eliminates some of these deductions and thus alters the difference between the statutory rate and the average effective rate.
statutorily: The agency plans to complete all statutorily required inspections by the end of May.

amendment: @ A change or changes made to the words of a text.
He insisted that the book did not need amendment.
I've made a few last-minute amendments to the article.
Presidential power was reduced by a constitutional amendment in 1991.
Tillers and cultivators are useful for turning soil, mixing in compost and fertilizer for soil amendment and loosening soil to help water reach plant roots.
regulation: @ An official rule or the act of controlling something.
The correct procedure is laid down in the rules and regulations.
I have acted strictly in accordance with the regulations at all times.
@ According to the rules or the usual way of doing things.
It's regulation to wear suits at the office.
@ Used to describe official clothes or equipment used by people in a particular type of work.
All flight attendants are required to wear regulation uniform
Security staff are issued with regulation kit.
Every week they come out with new regulations.
We're not going to get rid of all regulation.
This seriously threatens the idea that companies are going to move themselves to a similarly stable country simply because of less business regulation.

attorney: She's an attorney who advises companies about mergers and takeovers.
They paid a high-powered attorney to plead their case.
She was asked to take the witness stand and was then cross-examined by the state attorney.
The defense attorney requested an adjournment.
You may appoint an attorney to act on your behalf.
be tried: @ When a person is tried, he or she has to appear in a law court and is found innocent or guilty after the judge and jury have heard the evidence. When a legal case is tried, it is considered in a court of law.
He suggested that those responsible should be tried for crimes against humanity.
Whether he is innocent or guilty is a decision that will be made when the case is tried in court.

tried and tested/trusted: @ Used many times before and proved to be successful.
I'll give my mother's tried and tested recipe for wholewheat bread.

delinquency: @ Behavior, esp. of a young person, that is illegal or not acceptable to most people
There is a high rate of juvenile delinquency in this area.
His past delinquencies have made it hard for him to get a job.
accuse: @ To say that someone has done something morally wrong, illegal, or unkind.
The surgeon was accused of negligence.

stand accused of sth: @ If you stand accused of doing something wrong, people say that you have done it.
The government stands accused of eroding freedom of speech.
accusation: He denied the accusation, saying he was innocent.
He glared at me with an air of accusation.
What do you say to the accusation that you are unfriendly and unhelpful?

allegation: @ A statement, made without giving proof, that someone has done something wrong or illegal.
Several of her patients have made allegations of professional misconduct against her.
Allegations that Mr. Dwight was receiving money from known criminals have caused a scandal.
The chief executive of the company resigned last autumn over allegations about his expenses.
She rejected the allegation that she had treated her staff unfairly.
He made allegations of unfair dismissal against his former employers.

resolve: His words were comforting, even if they didn't resolve her concerns.

solve: & Solve is more like answering a question, like in homework or math problem. Resolve is like fixing an argument.

utter: She sat through the whole meeting without uttering a word.

utterly: & Utterly is slightly more literary. It can also be more emphatic or with emotion, for example "I'm utterly disgusted with you".
totally: & Totally literally means ' Completely ' but it isn't very emphatic.

peal: @ When bells peal, they rising with a loud sound.
After their wedding, the bells pealed out from the tower.
@ A long loud sound or series of sounds, esp. of laughter or thunder.
Her suggestion was met with peals of laughter.
A loud peal of thunder woke him from restless sleep.
When we heard the peal of the bells, we knew a truce had been declared.
hiss: @ To make a noise like a long s sound.
I heard a hiss and a pop as the cork came out of the bottle.
Peoplein the audience were hissing their disapproval.
@ To say something in a quiet angry way.
exclaim: @ To say or shout something suddenly because of surprise, fear, pleasure, etc.
As she passed, they would stop her and exclaim "Gee Your Hair Smell Terrific!".
She exclaimed with delight when she saw the baby.

strangle: She had been strangled with her own scarf and her body dumped in to the woods.

suffocate: & You suffocate when you're strangled, but you're not necessarily being strangled when you suffocate.

complaint: We've received a complaint from one of our listeners about offensive language.

complain: & Complain is the verb form of Complaint, which is the noun form.

undertone: It was a comedy act with an undertone of cruelty.
The elephants' pale gray skin carries undertones of violet.
John's description of his ex-wife had an undertone of sadness.

overtone: & Undertone usually means an unspoken meaning that the speaker doesn't mean to send.
& Overtone usually means an unspoken meaning that they speakers wants to send.
John's conversation with Jane had romantic overtones.

underlying: And what might be the underlying significance of these supposedly random acts?
The underlying message of the film is that love transcends everything else.
It's important to look at all the underlying causes of the conflict.
Though she was a good worker, her underlying compassion made her the boss's favorite.
The investigation focused on the underlying causes of the fire.
@ Used to describe something on which something else is based.
The price of the investment fell below the value of the underlying assets.
@ Positioned under the surface of something.
The currents are affected by the shape of the underlying rocks.

potential: As a economics major, she has a potential career in business.

connote: The word ' warrior ' connotes honour and bravery as well as fierceness in battle.
To me, chocolate connotes pleasure and idulgence.

connotation: The word ' lady ' has connotations of refinement and excessive femininity that some women find offensive.
' Resolute ' means stubborn, but with a more positive connotation.
These days, trangendered has negative connotations and transgender is widely considered proper, though it remains open to debate, as does its definition.

denote: The color red used to denote passion or danger.
His angry tone denoted extreme displeasure.
The vertical line denotes the relative abundance of vertebrate remains in the various depositional environments.
The period saw the radical separation of micro- and macro-economics (a separation denoted, paradoxically, as a ' neoclassical synthesis ').
imply: I'm not implying anything about your cooking, but could we eat out tonight?
@ To involve something or make it necessary.
The report, which is viewed as a bellwether for economic trends, implied that the national economy could be slowing down.
Her statement implies a lack of confidence in the management of the company.
A connection between the events has been implied in several new reports.

infer: & The main difference between these two words is that a speaker can imply, but a listener can only infer.
Then I think we must infer from what they said that they believe we should reapply for the job.
implication: Because of security implications the officers were tried in secret.
The implications of these findings are intriguing, to say the least.
@ An occasion when you seem to suggest something without saying it directly.
From what she said, the implication was that they were splitting up.
@ An occasion when you suggest or show that someone is involved in a crime.
The case depended upon his implication of his co-workers in the fraud.
@ The effect that an action or decision will have on something else in the future.
The company is cutting back its spending and I wonder what the implications will be for our department.
What are the implications of the new law?

suggest: I suggested putting the matter to the committee.
Does anything suggest itself? (= Do you have any ideas about what we should do?).
His manner suggested a lack of interest in what we were doing.
She has applied for a lot of jobs recently, which suggests that she's not altogether happy with her position.

suggestion: I don't know what to wear tonight - do you have any suggestion?
hint: He has dropped several hints to the boss that he'll quit if he doesn't get a promotion.
You can't take (= understand) a hint, can you? Just go away and leave me alone!
I detected a hint of doubt in his voice.
There's just a hint of brandy in the sauce.
advise: & Advise is usually given by experts while suggest is not.
His doctor advised him against smoking.
Guests were advised to pay special attention to hand hygiene.

advice: I think I'll take your advice and get the green dress.
Moreover, a panel is now allowed to seek information and technical advice from any individual or body which it deems appropriate.

instruction: @ Something that someone tells you to do.
The police who broke into the house were only acting on/under instructions.
He gave me strict intructions to get there by eight o'clock.
@ Advice and information about how to do or use something, often written in a book or on the side of a container.
The cooking instructions say to bake it for half an hour.
You obviously didn't read th instructions properly.
They need clear instructions on what to do next.
@ The teaching of a particular skill or subject.
The video provides instruction on how to operate the computer.
Have you seen the instruction manual for the washing machine?
@ The act of teaching someone how to do something.
The course gives you basic instruction in car maintenance and repairs.

proposal: Congress has rejected the latest economic proposal put forward by the President.
The president's proposal was to tax a percentage of Social Security benefits for high-income people.
Management has made proposals to cap overtime.
@ An official document in which you give information about yourself and your property for an insurance agreement.
Once you completed the on-screen proposal form, the premium and cover details are sent to you by e-mail.

insurance: @ An agreement in which you pay a company money and they pay your costs if you have an accident, injury, etc.
I'll need to take out extra car insurance for another driver.
The insurance doesn't cover you for (= include) household items.
I claimed on the insurance for the damage to the furniture.
@ Money that is paid by an insurance company.
I had to cancel the trip, but I got back nearly $1000 in insurance.
contract: @ A legal document that states and explains a formal agreement between two different people or groups, or the agreement itself.

stubborn: @ A stubborn person is determined to do what he or she wants and refuses to do anything else.
They have huge arguments because they're both so stubborn.
@ Things that are stubborn are difficult to move, change, or deal with.
He was famed for his stubborn resistance and his refusal to accept defeat.
Stubborn stains can be removed using a small amount of detergent.

resolute: @ Determined in character, action, or ideas.
& ' Resolute ' means stubborn, but with a more positive connotation.
She's utterly resolute in her refusal to apologize.
I admired her resolute optimism in those difficult times.

resolutely: She resolutely refuses to lower her standards.
The whole team was resolutely optimistic.

nosy: @ Being nosy is being too interested in what other people are doing and wanting to discover too much about them.
@ When someone tries to join in on other people's business. More like a curious person with a negative negation attached to it.

gossip: @ The story people are talking about. But often also used to describe someone.
@ "She's a gossip." meaning if she finds out about it , she will talk about it with her friends and so on, story won't be a secret no more.

toss: Indeed, dwarf tossing is an Olympic sport!

throw: & ' Toss ' tends to be weaker. It can also mean put. It doesn't always mean you are letting something fly out of you hand.
disposal: @ The act or process of getting rid of something, esp. by throwing it away.
This agency regulates the disposal of hazardous substances.
The manufacturing process is being changed in an effort to reduce waste disposal costs.
@ Something is sold by a company, such an asset, property, or part of its business, or the act of doing this.
The company is looking at the disposal of non-core operations.
The company has launched a disposal program to generate cash.
@ A situation in which it is stated that a debt does not need to be paid or will never be paid.
The company also put aside 5.29 billion yen in reserves for disposal of bad debt.

at someone's disposal: @ Available to be used by someone.
I would take you if I could, but I don't have a car at my disposal this week.
Having sold the house she had a large sum of money at her disposal (= to spend as she wanted).

hygiene: The modern system of hygiene is in great part founded upon decent pathology.
& Hygiene is how well you take care of yourself. If you have good hygiene, you take regular showers, brush your teeth a lot, wash you hair, etc.

hygienic: I suppose warm-air hand-driers are more hygienic than hand-towels, and paper towels create a lot of litter.

sanitation: & Sanitation is to keep something clean and germ free. Hand sanitizer, for example, kills the germs on your hands.
sanitary: The city is well supplied with water and its sanitary state is good.

antiseptic: @ As a noun, it's a chemical used to prevent infection from an injury, esp. by killing bacteria.
Antiseptic is used to sterilize the skin before giving an injection.
Many of the ingredients for antiseptics come from the rainforests.
In the 1870s and 1880s, doctors began to follow the principles of antiseptic surgery.

sterilize: @ To perform a medical operation on someone in order to make them unable to have children.
After having five children, she decided to be sterlized.
The clinic will sterilize your cat for free.
@ To make something completely clean and free from bacteria.
All equipment must be sterilized before use.

clinic: @ A building or part of a hospital where people go for medical care or advice.
Bring your baby to the clinic and we'll take a look at her.

clinical: @ Used to refer to medical work or teaching that relates to the examination and treatment of ill people.
She recently underwent a clinical evaluation in hospital.
Clinical tests have so far failed to show the cause of her illness.
She seems to have a very clinical attitude toward her children.
We were going to paint our kitchen white, but we decided that would look too clinical.

inject: @ To use a needle and syringe to put a liquid such as a drug into a person's body.
Phil's diabetic and has to inject himself with insulin everyday.
@ To introduce something new that is necessary or helpful to a situation or process.
A large amount of money will have to be injected into the company if it is to survive.
I tried to inject a little humor into the meeting.

injection: @ The act of putting a liquid, esp. a drug, into a person's body using a needle and a syringe.
Daily insulin injections are necessary for some diabetics.
This steroid is sometimes given by injection.
My arm was very tender after the injection.
@ The introduction of something new that is necessary or helpful to a situation or process.
A cash injection of $20 million will be used to improve the health service.

prenatal: @ Relating to the medical care given to pregnant women before their babies are born.
Prenatal clinics provide care for pregnant women.
medicinal: @ Medicinal substances are used to cure illesses.
It's said that the spring water has medicinal properties.

medicinally: This herbs has been used medicinally for centuries.
You can cook with them or use them medicinally, but don't underestimate their powers.
Medicinally, ginger helps settle the stomach and may be used to treat motion sickness.
The oil is used medicinally to boost the immune system.

anesthesia: @ The condition of not feeling pain, esp. by use of special drugs.
The procedure is performed under general anesthesia.

anesthetize: The vet anesthetized my dog to take xrays.
painkiller: The body produces chemicals that are natural painkillers.
opiate: @ A drug that contains opium, esp. one the causes sleep.

opium: @ A drug made from the seeds of a poppy (= red flower) that is used to control pain or to help people sleep. It can make a person who takes it want more of it and is sometimes used by people as an illegal drug for pleasure.
While most of the money from the opium trade floods into the black economy, some also reaches the insurgency.
poppy: Alternative uses for flowers wouldn't be complete without mentioning the poppy, used to make opium.

narcotic: @ An illegal drug such as heroin or cocaine.
He faces three years in jail for selling narcotics.
@ A drug that makes you want to sleep and prevents you feeling pain.

morphine: @ A drug made from opium, used to stop people from feeling pain or to make people feel calmer.

pathology: @ A branch of medical science that studies the nature, effects, causes and consequences of disease.

microorganisms: @ Technically a microorganism or microbe is an organism that is microscopic. The study of microorganisms is called microbiology. Microorganisms can be bacteria, fungi, archaea or protists. The term microorganisms does not include viruses and prion, which are generally classified as non-living.

microbe: @ It can be any microorganism, but specially said of those microorganisms which are harmful types of bacteria.
microscopic: @ An adjective as invisible or indistinguishable without the use of a microscope.

pathogen: @ An organism causing disease to its host, with the severity of the disease symptoms referred to as virulence.
germ: @ A very small organism that causes disease.
In warm weather these germs multiply rapidly.
@ The origin of something that develops, esp.
A cell from which grain grows or the beginning of an idea.
He found the germ of an idea in an old newspaper.
Alefandro's suggestion was the germ of the whole idea.

thrive: @ To grow, develop, or be successful.
His business thrived in the years before the war.
She seems to thrive on stress.

plankton: @ Very small plants and animals that float on the surface of the sea and on which other sea animals feed.
The giant plankton-feeders in today's oceans are among the largest living vertebrate animals alive.
bioluminescence: @ Light created by the body of a living creature, for example by some sea creatures and insects such as fireflies.
Plankton float in the ocean current, sparkling with bioluminescence.

yeast: You mix flour, yeast and water to make bread.

ferment: You make wine by leaving grape juice to ferment until all the sugar has turned to alcohol.
fungus: @ Plural fungi, any of about 144,000 known species or organisms of the kingdom Fungi, which includes the yeasts, rusts, smuts, mildews, molds, and mushrooms.

macro-: @ Large; relating to the whole of something, rather than its parts.
At a macro-level, economic trends play a fundamental role.
The state's ability to exercise macro-control was weakened.

macroscopic: @ Large enough to be seen by the human eye.
macroeconomics: @ The study of financial systems at a national level.
macro: @ A single instruction given to a computer that produces a set of instructions for the computer to perform a particular piece of work.
I've created a macro to spell check all the files at the same time.

external: @ of, on, for, or coming from the outside.
In external ways David had hardly changed at all.
This cream is for external use only (= it must not be put inside the body).
In later years, his paintings began to show a number of external influences (= influences coming from other people).
You shouldn't judge people by their external appearances.
@ Existing, intended for, or happening outside a person, organization, place, country, etc.
She handles the company's external relations.

externally: Externally the house is in need of repair.
Externally she appeared calm, but inside she was furious.

litter: @ Small pieces of trash that have been left lying on the ground in public places.
About two percent of fast-food packaging ends up as litter.

a litter of: @ A group of animals that are born at the same time and have the same mother.

damp: Unlike wood, however, it is completely unaffected by damp, rot, decay, frost or insect attack.

wet: & Damp means it's slight wet. The towel to wipe the spilled juice is damp from my sweaty hands.
drench: &  Wet means it's drenched in water or another liquid.
sopping: My hair is sopping (wet) from the shower I took.
flood: @ To cause to fill or become covered with water, esp. in a way that causes problems.
Our washing machine broke down yesterday and flooded the kitchen.
The whole town flooded when the river burst its banks.
@ To fill or enter a place in large numbers or amounts.
Donations are flooding into the homeless shelter.
Japanese cars have flooded the market (= a lot of them are on sale).
He was flooded with (= suddenly felt a lot of) joy when his first child was born.
@ A large amount or number of something
A flood of imports has come into the country.

in floods of tears: I found her in floods of tears in the toilets.
the Flood: @ In the Bible, a flood sent by God that covered the whole earth as a punishment.

spring up: Thousands of new businesses have sprung up in the past couple of years.

swamp: The Everglades are an area of swamp in southern Florida.
@ To cover a place with a large amount of water.
High tides have swamped the coast.
The boat was swamped by an enormous wave.
@ If something swamps a person, system, or place, more of it arrives than can be easily dealt with.
Foreign cars have swamped the U.K. market.
I'm swamped with work at the moment.
Don't let feelings of depression swamp you.
tide: @ The rise and fall of the ocean that happens twice every day.
You can only see the beach when the tide is out.
Most of people are completely clueless about tide directions and weather conditions.
@ A noticeable change in a situation or increase in a particular type of behavior.
We must look for ways of stemming (= stopping) the rising tide of protest.

monsoon: @ The season of heavy rain during the summer in hot Asian countries.
The failure of the monsoon would destroy harvests on which a billion people rely.
But this year, the monsoon is late and forecasters predict it may produce less rain than normal.
The heating up of these bodies of water generates tropical cyclones and monsoon rains.
And then last month, the monsoons arrived, like an answer to a prayer.

corruption: The film is about a young police officer and his struggle to expose corruption in the force.
Political corruption is widespread throughout the country.
@ In language, a word whose original form has been changed.
The swear word ' bloody ' is wrongly thought by some to be a corruption of the words "by our Lady".

mold: @ A soft, green or gray growth that develops on old food or on objects that have been left for too long in warm, wet air.
There was mold on the cheese.
@ A hollow container with a particular shape into which soft or liquid substances are poured, so that when the substance becomes hard it taks the shape of the container.
@ If someone is from or in a particular mold, they have the characteristics typical of a certain type of person.
He's cast in a very different mold from his brother.
He's a player in the Federer mold.
@ To try to change or influence someone.

@ To go around the edge of something.

@ To avoid discussing a subject or problem usually because there are difficulties that you don't want to deal with.

brooch: @ A small piece of jewelry with a pin at the back that is fastened to a woman's clothing.
badge: @ A small piece of metal or plastic with words or a picture on it, that you carry with you or fasten to your clothing or something else, in order to show who you are, that you are a member of a group, etc.

@ To put a badge or other mark on something.

@ To describe something in a particular way.

sequin: @ A small, shiny metal or plastic disk sewn onto clothes for decoration.

dictator: @ A leader who has complete power in a country and has not been elected by the people.

dictatorship: A flood of refugees fled the brutal dictatorship then existing in that country.

By any reasonable person's thinking; this set of unconstitutional powers represents nothing more than a -- presidential dictatorship.

authority: The United Nations has used/exerted/exercised its authority to restore peace in the area.

authoritarian: My father was a real authoritarian so we were brought up very strictly.

regime: The old corrupt, totalitarian regime was overthrown.

despotic: @ Having unlimited power over other people, and often using it unfairly and cruelly.

emperor: Hirohito was Emperor of Japan from 1926 until his death in 1989.

imperial: This type of porcelain was made specifically for the Chinese emperor and the imperial household.

The imperial guards stormed the palace.
@ The imperial system of measurement uses units such as inches, miles, and pints.
Imperial units have in many cases been replaced by metric ones in Britain.
totalitarian: @ Of or being a political system in which those in power have complete control and do not allow people freedom to oppose them.

colonial: @ Involving a perioud of political control by a more powerful country.

monopoly: @ An organization or group that has complete control of something, especially an area of business, so that others have no share.

fruitful: It was a most fruitful discussion, with both sides agreeing to adopt a common policy.

@ If a person is fruitful, they produce a lot of children.

abundance: @ The situation in which there is more than enough of something.

Grapes and olives grow in abundance in the valley.

abundant: There is abundant evidence that cars have a harmful effect on the environment.

excessive: Excessive exercise can sometimes cause health problems.

deprive: @ To take something, esp. something necessary or pleasant, away from someone.

You can't function property when you're deprived of sleep.
fruitless: @ If an action or attempt to do something is fruitless, it is unsuccessful or produces nothing of value.

After months of fruitless negotiations with team owners, the city withdrew its offer to build a new stadium.
scarcely: I could scarcely believe it when she said she wanted to marry me.

scarcity: @ A situation in which something is not easy to find or get.

A scarcity of flour makes bread, cake, and other baked goods more expensive.

barely: & ' barely ', ' scarcely ' and ' hardly ' are basically interchangeable.

handful: @ An amount of something that can be held in one hand.

@ A small number of people or things.

@ A person, often a child, who is difficult to control.
Her older son is fine but the little one is a bit of handful.

quasi-: Do companies need to be quasi-monopolies to survive in this new global economy?

unaided: @ According to the Oxford dictionary, unaided means ' without help from anyone or anything '

preserve: @ To keep something as it is, esp. in order to prevent it from decaying or being damaged or destroyed.

reserve: @ To keep something for a particular purpose or time.

@ If you reserve something such as a seat on an aircraft or a table at a restaurant, you arrange for it to be kept for your use.

@ The habit of not showing your feelings or thoughts.

@ The act of keeping something or a supply of something until it's needed, or a supply that you keep.
She keeps a little money in reserve (= for use if and when needed).
The librarian has put the book on reserve for me (= will keep it for me when it becomes available).
We still have a reserve for food in case of emergency.
@ An area of land kept in its natural state, esp. for wild animals to live in and be protected.
conserve: @ To keep and protect something from damage, change, or waste.

retain: @ To keep or continue to have something.

@ If a substance retains something, such as heat or water, it continues to hold or contain it.

retention: @ The continued use, existence, or possession of something or someone.

@ The ability to keep or continue having something.

retentive: @ If you have a retentive memory of brain, you can remember things easily.

shank: @ The part of the leg between the knee and ankle or the equivalent in animals.

frame: @ A border that surrounds and supports a picture, door, or window.

@ The basic structure of a building, vehicle, or piece of furniture that other parts are added onto.

@ A wooden or plastic triangle used to put the balls into position at the start of a game such as billiards.
@ The size and shape of someone's body.
My sister has a much bigger frame than me.

@ A period of play in some games, such as bowling.
She lost the next two frames.
@ One of the pictures on a strip of photographic film, or one of the single pictures that together form a television or movie.
@ To carefully plan or organize ideas, suggestions, methods, etc., in a particular way.

@ To make a person seem to be guilty of a crime when they are not, by producing facts or information that are not true.

@ To fix a border around a picture, etc. and often glass in front of it.

@ To form and edge to something in an attractive way.

frames: @ The plastic or metal structure that holds together a pair of glasses.
frame of mind: @ The way someone thinks or feels about something at a particular time.

frame of reference: @ A set of ideas or facts accepted by a person that explains his or her behavior, opinions, or decisions.

nerve: @ A group of long, thin fibers (= structures like threads) that carry information or instructions between the brain and other parts of the body.

nerves: @ Worry or anxiety about something that is going to happen.

hormonal: @ Feeling the effect of hormones, esp. when this makes your emotions stronger or more likely to change than usual.

hormone: @ Any of various chemicals made by living cells that influence the development, growth, sex, etc. of an animal and are carried around the body in the blood.

urine: @ A waste product of animals, typically liquid (solid in birds and reptiles) containing urea or uric acid.

acquire: To acquire wealth is difficult, to preserve it more difficult, but to spend it wisely most difficult of all.

derive: @ To get something from something else.

absorb: @ To take in a liquid, gas, or chemical.

demand: @ To ask for something forcefully, in a way that shows that you do not expect to be refused.

demands: @ The difficult things that you have to do.

recipient: @ A person or organization that receives something, such as money, a prize, etc.

revenue: @ The income that a government or company receives regularly.

stock: @ A supply of something for use or sale.

@ Money that people invest in the government, producing a fixed rate of interest.

@ Animals, such as cows or sheep, kept on a farm.
@ The degree to which a person or organization is popular and respected.

@ The family or group that a person or animal comes from.

@ A garden plant with small pleasant-smelling, brightly colored flowers.

in / out of stock: The new addition is out of stock in major bookstores.
the stocks: @ In the past, a wooden frame that was fixed around someone's feet, hands, and sometimes head, so that they were forced to sit or stand for a long time in public as a punishent.

bestow: & Endow means to give someone an ability or attribute. Bestow can also mean that, but usually it means to give someone an object or reward.

mescal: & Tequilla is a type of mescal, but a mescal cannot be a tequila.

carbonated: @ A carbonated drink is fizzy because it contains bubbles of carbon dioxide.

fizzy: Considering they all taste like somewhat moldy, watered, down, fizzy bread to me, it's moot.

nimble: @ Quick and exact either in movement or thoughts.

However, after two thousand years, the invitation is still open.
Not all family members accepted the invitation to attend the ceremony.
A martini glass tacked on to an invitation is a great heads up.

reject: @ To refuse to accept, use, or believe something or someone.
I applied for a job as a mechanic in a local garage, but I was rejected.
@ To not give someone the love and attention they want and are expecting from you.
When she was sent to boarding school, she felt as though her parents had rejected her.
@ If your body rejects an organ that has been put in during a medical operation, it fails to accept it and tries to attack and destroy it.
@ A product that is damaged or not perfectly made.
Most of the crowd control drugs tested by the US military were rejects from the pharmaceutical industry.
@ A person who has not been accepted by an organization or by society.
He considered himself to be one of life's rejects.

utopian: @ Relating to or aiming fora perfect society in which everyone works well with each other and is happy.
But the drudgery of running his own publication is already intruding on the utopian world he has built for himself.
And you think dance music is so free and open and it comes from this utopian ethos.
It wasn't so much a marketing catchphrase as a blueprint for a utopian future.
Now, the hot air balloon - with all of its utopian associations - has become a medium for his rather conceptual art.

dystopian: @ Relating to a very bad or unfair society in which there is a lot of suffering, especially an imaginary society in the future, or to the description of such a society.
She mentioned Margaret Atwood's dystopian novel ' The Handmaid's Tale, ' in which fertile young women are enslaved as reproductive servants.
George Orwell, author of the classic dystopian novel ' 1984 '.
The novel is set in a dystopian future in an America whose infrastructure has been reduced to rubble.

sluggish: @ Moving or operating more slowly than usual and with less energy or power.
A heavy lunch makes me sluggish in the afternoon.
Something is wrong with the car - the engine feels sluggish.
The housing market has been very sluggish these part few years.
Fierce competition and sluggish demand have resulted in very poor sales.

sluggishly: The band played sluggishly and appeared bored.
The stream runs sluggishly down from the hills in the April heat before the arrival of the June monsoon.
sluggishness: @ The quality or fact of being sluggish.
I've been experiencing a few minor health issues recently, such as fatigue and general sluggishness.
The market, despite its general economic sluggishness, is also expanding.

developer: @ A person or company that makes money from buying land, building new houses, offices, etc., or by changing existing buildings to sell or rent.
Much of the region's native vegetation has been damaged by developers who are building hotels along the coast.
The developers refurbished the house inside and out.
The project suddenly got a new lease of life when the developers agreed to provide some more funding.
The developers dealt with the problem in the time-honored fashion: burying the industrial waste in landfill sites.
@ A person or company that creates new products, esp. computer products such as software.
The company is a leading software developer.
@ A chemical used for developing photographs or films.
@ Someone, esp. a child, whose physical or mental development can be described in a particular way.

fixer: @ Someone who is skilled at arranging for things to happen, sometimes in a way that is dishonest.
They chose him because of his reputation as a fixer and an expert at handling difficult situations.

forestry: @ The science or industry of planting and taking care of large areas of trees.
He studied forestry at Colorado State University.
Good forestry always has required we put the next generation ahead of our own.
State forestry officials estimate about eighty percent of the eight-hundred thousand acres of wetland forest in the state is privately owned

waterfront: @ A part of a town that is next to an area of water such as a river or the ocean.
She owns a popular tourist restaurant on the town's waterfront.
But affordable real estate and waterfront views don't have millennials biting.
He was on the waterfront and watched as rescue personnel brought several survivors ashore.
His plan is to place life-size bronze statues along the town's waterfront.

adequate: @ Enough or satisfactory for a particular purpose.
He didn't have adequate time to prepare for the exam.

adequacy: We must re-examine the adequacy of our current security procedures.
adequately: Were you adequately paid, or do you need more money?
